Why is Hamilton on the $10 Bill? Richard Brookhiser, WSJ. @rbrookhiser

"...Hamilton as Treasury secretary adopted two strategies for handling the debt. The first was for the new federal government, as reorganized under the Constitution he had helped ratify, to assume the debts of all the states, along with its own. The second was a policy of nondiscrimination: All holders of U.S. debt would be paid at a common rate.

"Both policies were controversial. States that had already paid their debts resented shouldering the burdens of deadbeats. Nondiscrimination seemed like a gift to speculators: Everyone agreed that soldiers who had been mustered out with IOUs should finally be rewarded for their service. But should sharpies who had bought IOUs at discounts, when it seemed as if they might never be redeemed, be rewarded too?

"Hamilton argued for mutual respect and realism. States like Massachusetts were not deadbeats but brothers who had spent heavily in a common struggle. Nondiscrimination was the price for entering the debt market: Borrowers who played favorites among their creditors would soon find no one willing to extend them credit.

Hamilton saw it as a way of both increasing and regulating the money supplyâ€”a boon to a cash-poor economy. Hamiltonâ€™s Federalist collaborator, James Madison, thought the bank was illegalâ€”the Constitution mentioned no such thing. Hamilton argued that a bank was necessary to fulfill a function the Constitution did mentionâ€”borrowing money on the credit of the United Statesâ€”therefore it was an implied power.
